Netanyahu may have succeeded in neutralizing the public effect of his investigations. But an Israeli prime minister, unlike a U.S. president, can easily be deposed. There is no need for lengthy impeachment hearings. All it will take is 61 Knesset members agreeing to vote in favor of an alternative prime minister.

Just to give you some facts. The Kneset is going  out for a recess till Oct 14th. At that time no gathering will be made or laws will be put to a vote. To gather the members you need 25 knesent members to raise a gathering offer to the chairman. 
As I see things here in Israel, Netanyahu will never resign without going to elections with a very high probability to win again. Due to our current military situation there is an unwritten law that will put aside political disputes. So, if I'm looking for a possibility to have a confidence lost (which is by means of gathering and vote turning towards it) there is a very little chance it will happen. If we look for elections call (by some reports it was for Jan/Feb not earlier) not a chance. Resignation? not Bibi.

Early elections are a matter of when rather than if. Bibi is investigated on four counts of fraud and opinion polls suggest that he'd win an early election. His ultra-orthodox partners also want early elections. Note that an election will put all the investigations on hold until after the elections. However, that decision might wait until after the local elections in October.

Seems to me that some of the issues related to Netanyahu wanting early elections have gone away. 
I had been following the issue of whether the Knesset would pass legislation to lower the threshold for entering the Knesset because that was an obstacle for Netanyahu if he called early elections, he needed some of the smaller parties' support. The idea was that if elections were called early, those parties would vanish. Seems lowering the threshold doesn't work if minority parties unite and form one list so a new idea has been introduced to limit funding for "lists" to the top parties in the coalition. This is aimed straight at Arab representatives.
https://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2018/06/israel-likud-yoav-kisch-arab-knesset-members-joint-list-bill.html

Will he resign, lose a vote of confidence or call new elections? Why resign? He’s popular and would win an election. His party has no viable alternatives. So - basically no.
Will he stir things up with Syria or Iran (with a nod from a Tsar Vlad the Shirtless) as a distraction? Possible.

This is an initial, naive forecast. I have a number of Israelis in my social network and while not all of them approve of Netanyahu's leadership none of them seem to expect he will be out of power any time soon. Additionally I recall that during a recent election his party was projected to do poorly but in fact managed to gain several seats. Israeli relations with the US have never been better since the election of Trump and a number of Israelis (correctly or not) seem to be crediting Bibi for that. However the number of scandals and investigations facing him is large, so I don't think it is extremely unlikely that public opinion could change.
I think it's very unlikely he will resign - from my knowledge that isn't typical of Israeli politicians and certainly not expected given Bibi's personality in particular. The other two possibilities are unlikely in my (admittedly poorly informed) opinion, but are much more plausible than resignation.
The will of the Israeli people.

I'm increasing the odds because it looks a little more likely Bibi will be indicted on corruption charges in the next month or two. If he's indicted and formally charged it will only be because the prosecutors are convinced the have an open and shut case. If that doesn't happen, the odds of his losing power decrease to, like, 2%.
WoC @ 25%. When are elections legally normally due? If you're going to be reelected easily why call it early, especially if you want to be in power for longer.
He has been on the winning side of too many issues lately, with the Iran deal and now threats from Iran.  His popularity is up and will stay up.

He is too close to being the longest running prime minister to volunteer a weakness. That isn't in his character. So he will not call for an election nor resign. Those who support him have yet to jump ship, nor those against him become radically vocal. He could receive a vote of no confidence, but those wheels would need to turn longer (most likely). But I believe more would need to drip or pour out first.

Netanyahu confidant to testify against him
* Police would not confirm whether long-time aide Shlomo Filber would testify against Netanyahu, but all the major Israeli media outlets said a deal to do so had been reached.
*  Filber, the former director of the Communications Ministry under Netanyahu, is under arrest on suspicion of promoting regulation worth hundreds of millions of dollars to Israel's Bezeq telecom company.
*  Netanyahu has denied all the charges, calling them part of a media-orchestrated witch hunt that has swept up the police and prosecution as well, and has vowed to carry on.

"...It should be noted that twice in the past, the police have recommended charging Netanyahu on suspicions of fraud and breach of trust, and twice the cases against him were closed, accompanied by a critical public report that did nothing to harm his political career or popularity. It appears that the difference this time is that the offenses that Netanyahu is accused of are more serious, involving allegations of receiving a million shekels worth of favors, and in Case 2000, allegations of a deal that would have delivered a major blow to freedom of the Israeli press.  The police recommendations now must be considered by Attorney General Avichai Mendelblit. What is expected of him at the moment is to decide as quickly as possible rather than deliberating endlessly in the lead-up to zero hour and a decision on whether to indict."

Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu continues to maintain a strong position and the confidence of Israeli voters.  He will survive the investigations.

While there is a formidable array of legal cases being brought against Netanyahu, there are a variety of advantages in his favor. He has the most supportive US administration in modern history. The declaration of Jerusalem as the Israeli capital by the US has increased strife as Palestine categorically rejects this. Historically, Likud in general and Netanyahu in particular has benefited from rising tensions. He also has a variety of enemies that he can invoke to mobilize public opinion - not only the Palestinians, but the specter of a US pullout of the nuclear agreement with Iran, and the war in Syria. Of these scenarios the one I find most likely is that he will call new elections, but even on that front the rise of extreme right wing parties in Israel suggests that his supporters would mobilize to help him win.

I don't see Netanyahu resigning under any circumstance. His coalition has 61 out of 120 seats in the Knesset. It's possible that he loses a vote of confidence given how many individuals he has to placate to continue to govern, but I don't see any figures in the wings ready to wrest control from him. Israel's economy is doing okay, and Netanyahu has presided over relative calm in a region on fire, so I don't see voters or coalition partners ditching him without really good cause.
